posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: Our first year implementing full-field localization, the system runs smoothly, yet maintaining accurate pose remains challenging. Our primary goal is automating alignment across all reef positions. We're referencing Spartronics' Pathplanner whitepaper for drive-to-pose implementation. Questions include how to adjust standard deviations and if there are alternative tuning methods. Currently, we avoid additional filtering, directly inputting vision data into the Swerve DrivePose Estimator. How have others approached this challenge?

posts.name: Jade
posts.cooked: Data filtering and tuning your stddevs are two key concepts you've covered here. For data filtering, examining the AdvantageKit vision template serves as a solid starting point. This involves using known value ranges to identify and discard erroneous measurements. Stddevs represent the accuracy of your position measurements, with higher values reducing trust in those measurements. They should ideally be kept low to maintain pose stability, though they shouldn't be zero as measurements never perfectly match reality. Tuning involves adjusting these values based on specific detection patterns, leveraging resources like the AdvantageKit template for guidance. While camera calibration and motion tearing significantly impact pose accuracy, utilizing telemetry data helps pinpoint inaccuracies.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
Our team achieved full field localization last year, and this year we gained significant insights into improving the accuracy of our system through various tunings. Below are our key takeaways:

Filtering bad results involves rejecting many outcomes to ensure we only retain high-quality data. We perform basic checks on latency and ambiguity to determine if an estimate is worth processing further; however, the process becomes more intricate afterward. Additionally, we exclude any results indicating the robot is outside the field.

When the robot is inactive, we further filter out impossible results due to multi-camera verification. If a pose estimate places the robot in a position that another camera cannot observe, it is deemed incorrect. This feature is particularly useful when the robot is stationary but becomes problematic during movement, causing increased load on the RoboRIO and vision threads.

Weighing results requires adjusting a matrix that influences how we trust each pose estimate. By dynamically modifying this matrix based on pose quality, we prioritize reliable results while minimizing the weight of less trustworthy ones. Details on this method can be found in a previous post.

link_counts.title: Localization: Finding Standard Deviations for SetVisionMeasurementStdDevs

posts.name: Mete Karadeniz
posts.cooked: You’re definitely on the right path. From our experience, the two biggest things that improved pose accuracy were proper filtering and tuning stddevs. Raw vision data without filtering can easily throw off your pose. AdvantageKit’s vision template is a great reference—they reject data with high ambiguity, bad latency, or positions off the field. Adding even simple checks like those made a big difference for us. For stddevs, think of them as how much you trust the vision. Lower equals more trust, higher equals less. But they should never be zero. Tuning them right means finding the balance between trusting good data and ignoring bad data. Some teams adjust stddevs dynamically based on tag quality—AdvantageKit does this too—and it’s a solid starting point. Also, don’t overlook camera calibration and motion blur—they matter more than you’d think. Using telemetry to see where your errors come from helps a ton.

posts.name: Muaz
posts.cooked: We rely heavily on combining vision estimates with odometry through WPILib’s SwervePoseEstimator to enhance our system’s accuracy. While odometry itself is reliable, integrating it with vision data minimizes errors caused by wheel slippage. Additionally, maintaining odometry as a fallback ensures functionality even when visual data is unavailable.

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: We use WPI's pose estimator; it fuses together already.

posts.name: Prince
posts.cooked: Thank you @irresistiable and @spacey_sooty for the reference to advantage Kit’s vision template. I will definitely look into replicating the entire code but not within the advantage kit's setup. Any help or examples would be very appreciated.
